nuclear targeted gold nanoparticles to
monitor different biological processes
in real time but before we get into the

I think this slide pretty much sums it

enough
to collaborate with a postdoc bin king

throughout my career I've always
utilized gold nanoparticles so I just
wanted to give a little bit of a
background of why I enjoy working with
gold nanoparticles and why I think
they're so great if we look at this
scale here we can see that a lot of
important biological molecules lie in
the range between 1 and 100 nanometers
and it's no coincidence that these gold
nanoparticles being dubbed nano also lie
in this range and so they're comparable
in size so important biological
molecules and therefore can interact
with these molecules but in particular
for gold nanoparticles on being a
Metallica nanoparticle knees on this
nano scale on they have unique optical
and physical properties and in
particular they were able to strongly
scatter light much much more efficiently
than typical for force or conventional
fluorophores so we can actually leverage
that characteristic when we're
monitoring and detecting low levels of
biological molecules and potentially
complex environments so when we wanted
to set out and develop a system that we
could monitor biological
processes in real time we needed to
create a probe that could allow us to do
that and so for that we synthesized gold
nanoparticles and functionalize them
with peptides that would allow them to
be internalized into the cell but also
localize at the nucleus where a lot of
these important events are occurring and
to leverage the strong light scattering
that allowed us to one collect Rayleigh
scattering from these cell samples and
so in that way we're able to acquire
morphological information of these cells
over time using just a conventional dark
field microscope but additionally
because these particles scatter light so
strongly they're able to amplify rather
low signals such as raman vibrations so
here we can actually get a molecular
fingerprint of these cellular events by
monitoring the Raman spectra over time
so we were able to apply this nuclear
targeted gold nanoparticle raman set up
to a bunch of different intracellular
processes but i really wanted to focus
on these two applications that we looked
into evaluating drug efficacy over time
as well as monitoring drug delivery in
real time so in terms of evaluating drug
efficacy we first needed to see one can
these nanoparticles localize at the
nucleus which we can see on C and this
inlay here is possible but also get an
amplified raman signal and that's what
we see here in this raman spectra in the
biological fingerprint region we see we
get very clear distinct signals and if
we take these nuclear targeted treated
cells and treat them with common
chemotherapeutics such as cisplatin or
five flurry or so we can see distinct
changes over time in particular if we
look at the cellular imaging we can see
that our cells have now started to
shrink and the light scattering has been
amplified and this is indicative of a
cell undergoing cell death or apoptosis
but more importantly for us since we
really wanted to monitor the molecular
changes over time if we look at these
we can see that their distinct
vibrational changes that occur after
therapeutic treatment in particular we
have a decrease in the 500 wave number
band but we also get a simultaneous
increase in the thout 1000 and around
1600 wave number region and so we're
actually able to correlate these changes
two distinct alterations in these
biological molecules so for the first
two vibrations at 500 and 1000 that's
actually representing proteins
denaturing while these cells are
undergoing cell death in the higher wave
number band at 1585 is actually
indicating that there's possible DNA
damage occurring on during cell death
and I didn't show it here but we were
able to actually compare this process
the typical cell viability assays such
as X CT and MTD and because we have on
these nuclear targeted particles which
are able to amplify these signals on the
molecular level we're actually able to
get out drug efficacy comparisons
between different chemotherapeutic drugs
in a shorter time frame so as a grad
student who wanted to graduate I found
this pretty appealing but another thing
that we were able to do was to show that
we were able to track drug delivery over
time so um we took our nuclear targeted
gold nanoparticles and but also
functionalized them with a common chemo
therapeutic drug doxorubicin it has a
distinct raman vibration but also is
fluorescent on its own and so when
doxorubicin is functionalized to the
surface of these gold nanoparticles the
raman vibration of doxorubicin will be
greatly enhanced because of the strong
light scattering of these gold
nanoparticles but also because these
nanoparticles have unique optical
optical properties the fluorescence is
actually clenched of this doxorubicin
and so the linker that we chose to use
was ph-sensitive so that when these
cells in
when these gold nanoparticles are
actually internalized into the cell and
they were closed in to the lysosome
before heading to the movies this poor
sensitive linker will be crude therefore
releasing the doxorubicin molecule and
therefore the dock service and
fluorescence will be restored however
the raman vibrations will actually be
decreased and so we could see that we
were able to track this over time where
when we initially treated the cells um
you can see a strong wrong and vibration
of doxorubicin Harper's fluorescence is
quenched but as these nanoparticles
travel through the cell into different
organelles specifically the lysosome
where the huge drops we see that this
ramen signature disappears however the
fluorescence is restored so with this
who are unable to monitor drug delivery
in real time which we thought was pretty
exciting so in terms of what's next um
since I'm in the pharmaceutical world
now being able to miniaturize and
automate the system would be really
advantageous um the system that we were
using was a regular microscope that was
modified to have that cleared optics and
have a life searching but but if we
couldn't imagine doing this in a 96-well
could we could do high-throughput drug
screening and since now I'm working in
the discovery space were three optional
a bunch of molecules at in a short time
kick so in terms of interest at least
for me personally in terms of in vivo
applications if we could employ our drug
delivery and localization application to
an in vivo setting where we're trying to
assess tumor targeting as well as seeing
whether certain chemo therapeutic is
actually a fake ases efficacious in that
environment that would be a really great
step forward but also there have been
some groups that are not only using it
to identify specific tumors but they're
also using it as an inter operative tool
where they're using hi raman signals
within the tumor to actually resect the
tumor margins to make
sure that they're actually eliminating
and removing the tumor and the diseased
